p: Electrolyte and water imbalances can occur in COVID-19 resulting from insensible loss caused by high fever and tachypnea, gastrointestinal loss such as vomiting and diarrhea, as well as the inability to take adequate fluids because of an impaired level of consciousness [ 52]. Hypokalemia had been documented that has been attributed to upregulation of the RAAS by degradation of ACE2 by SARS-CoV-2 with increased renal loss of potassium [ 53, 54]. Clinicians must be vigilant regarding possible electrolyte imbalances and should titrate any corticosteroid or desmopressin doses accordingly. If intranasal desmopressin cannot be administered because of impaired consciousness, it can be converted to a parenteral form (IV/IM) to allow more stringent titration [ 52].
